newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australia 97/98 lead output seen up - ABARE.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australia 97/98 lead output seen up - ABARE.

text.p: Australian lead mine output is expected to rise 8.5 percent to 575,000 tonnes in the 1997/98 year to June 30, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) said in its March quarterly report.
The main production increase in 1997/98 are expected to come from the start of The Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd's Cannington mine in Queensland in late 1997, the bureau said.

ABARE said 1996/97 output is expected to rise to 530,000 tonnes from 505,000 tonnes in 1995/96. This rise is expected to come from Pasminco Ltd's Broken Hill and Elura mines in New South Wales and Rosebery mine in Tasmania, the bureau said.
Normandy Mining Ltd's Woodcutters mine and MIM Holdings Ltd McArthur River mine, both in the Northern Territory would also add to the production increase in 1996/97, ABARE said.
The bureau said lead export earnings are expected to rise 5.8 percent to A$493 million in 1997/98 from A$466 million in 1996/97 and up from A$456 million in 1995/96.
World lead mine production is forecast to rise 2.7 percent to 2.85 million tonnes in calendar 1997 and to rise by a further 7.9 percent to 3.07 million tonnes in 1998, it said.
The forecast rise in 1997 is based partly on the assumption that the Faro mine in Canada will re-open in early 1997 after its temporary shut-down at the end of 1996, ABARE said.

World lead metal consumption is forecast to rise by two percent in 1997 driven mainly by stronger lead battery consumption associated with higher global motor vehicle production, the government commodity advisory body said.

ABARE said global lead consumption is forecast to rise 1.9 percent in 1998. "The slightly lower rate if increase compared with 1997 mainly reflects assumed slower industrial production growth in OECD countries," it said.
Average world lead prices are forecast to fall by about three percent to US$750 a tonne in calendar 1997 and to fall to $680 a tonne in 1998 as additional mine supplies become available.
